channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-7784] move the code related to compaction selection specific to default compaction policy, into default compaction policy (from HStore)
item.description: There are some TODO [level compaction] in HBASE-7603 patch, there may also be few other similar places.
item.summary: move the code related to compaction selection specific to default compaction policy, into default compaction policy (from HStore)

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Also addresses HBASE-7791, kinda; if the system calculation produces USER_PRIORITY, priority is decreased (logically decreased) by one.

Looks good to me. One question, why do we want to do that?


+      if (priority == Store.PRIORITY_USER) {

+        ++priority; // System compactions cannot have user priority, make less important.

+      }

If there are lots of files to compact, priority could be negative here, which is higher than PRIORITY_USER, right?

Yes; see HBASE-7791
I am assuming this is intentional, as for default store, that means the store is blocked.

This message is automatically generated.

Yes; see HBASE-7791

I am assuming this is intentional, as for default store, that means the store is blocked.

Then why do you want this?

++priority; // System compactions cannot have user priority, make less important.
Because the collision of values with USER_PRIORITY causes fake USER_PRIORITY compactions (this affects some logic that compares == USER_PRIORITY)

I see. I prefer to move this logic change/fix to HBASE-7791, and just do the refactory in this one. But it is ok.

You call it system compaction priority because it is not set by user? Why not just getCompactionPriority()?


+  @Override

+  public int getSystemCompactionPriority(final Collection<StoreFile> storeFiles) {

+    return this.comConf.getBlockingStorefileCount() - storeFiles.size();

+  }
removing HBASE-7791 part, will fix it there
wrt method name - yes. Just to make it explicit it doesn't have to bother with user priority logic, HStore will do that
minor note: Don't you need to change FIXED_OVERHEAD in HStore (changed long to int)? I guess TestHeapSize should fail.

+1 from me.

looks good to me +1

Thanks for the reviews, Jimmy and Matteo.

The test failure seems to be caused by TestHBaseFsck being stuck in teardown of minicluster... I've seen this test fail in some other JIRA recently.

I ran the test based on latest trunk:
